DOC.HEADLINE: Statoil expects to restart Snorre A oil production this week

TEXT.P: Statoil ASA said Tuesday it expects to restart its Snorre A offshore petroleum platform later this week, almost a month after a natural gas leak shut down operations.
The state-controlled oil company said it hopes full production from Snorre and the satellite field Vigdis will resume by Dec. 31.

Snorre A, a steel tension-leg platform, was shut down Nov. 28 after a gas leak that resulted in the evacuation of 180 workers. The shutdown of Snorre and the Vigdis field meant a loss of 205,000 barrels of oil a day in production, or 6.4 percent of Norway's roughly 3.2 million barrels a day of production.
Norway is the world's third-largest oil exporter after Saudi Arabia and Russia.
Statoil pumped cement into the production well to permanently cap it and prevent any further leaks.
"A startup depends in part on maintaining our schedule for the remaining work," said Oivind Reinertsen, Statoil's senior vice president for the Tampen cluster of fields, which includes Snorre.
"We must also complete the planned inspection program with a positive result. But if everything goes according to plan, we should be back in normal operation before Dec. 31," he said.

Statoil also said it submitted a report on its progress in sealing the well to the Norwegian Petroleum Safety Authority on Tuesday, and that resuming crude oil flows also depends on the authority giving the go-ahead.

Statoil was founded by the government in 1972 to oversee the nation's petroleum interests, and employs about 17,000 people in 25 countries. The company was partly privatized in 2001 when the state sold a 17.5 percent stake to investors.
